I’d personally refine the question to “how many physical things exist now” and I’d answer with an upper bound of 2^(3*10^80)
3*10^80 is the number of particles and the 2^ is every possible subset of those particles, since any physical thing can pretty much be described as “these specific particles”
The vast majority of these would be nonsense sets of random particles throughout the universe, but within this massive set would contain every physical thing

I would consider there are only as many things as elements known currently to our knowledge, and subatomic particles that make up those atoms.

I've rewatched this video and come to the same conclusion. Michael massively underestimates the number of "things," because he uses a confused standard. The number of things actually thought is far less than his estimate, while the number of things that could be thought is far, far greater. Turning all the matter in the universe into brains (or computer parts) isn't actually possible anyway, so that is a red herring. And anyway, the question isn't "how many thoughts could a perfect computer the size of the universe think in ideal circumstances," the question was "how many things are there?" There are physical, real things that we have never thought about. Nobody has ever thought about the collection of an ipod, a stove, a novel, a bottle, a cupboard, a car, a light fixture, a toad, smoke, justice, the nasal septum, and a painting together before. Ever. And they never will again, unless they read this comment. Nevertheless, that collection is a real "thing," and so is every other such arbitrary collection I could come up with. So Michael misses the overwhelming majority of things by only counting the total number we could actually think, instead of the total number of things available to be thought.

Me:
How many fingers am I holding up?

Vsauce:
You might say, well, I know where my fingers are. I'm looking right at them. Or, I can touch them, I can feel them, they're right here and that's good. Your senses are a great way to learn things. In fact, we have way more than the usual five senses we talk about. For instance, your kinesthetic sense, proprioception. This is what the police evaluate during a field sobriety test. It allows you to tell where your fingers and arms and head and legs in your body is all in relation to each other without having to look or touch other things. We have way more than five senses, we have at least twice as many and then some. But they're not perfect.

There are optical illusions, audio illusions, temperature sensation illusions, even tactile illusions. Can you turn your tongue upside down? If so, perfect. Try this. Run your finger along the outer edge of the tip of your upside down tongue. Your tongue will be able to feel your finger, but in the wrong place. Our brains never needed to develop an understanding of upside down tongue touch. So, when you touch the right side of your tongue when it's flipped over to your left side you perceive a sensation on the opposite side, where your tongue usually is but isn't when it's upside down. It's pretty freaky and cool and a little humbling, because it shows the limits of the accuracy of our senses, the only tools we have to get what's out there in here.

The philosophy of knowledge, the study of knowing, is called epistemology. Plato famously said that the things we know are things that are true, that we believe and that we have justification for believing. those justifications might be irrational or they might be rational, they might be based on proof, but don't get too confident because proven is not a synonym for true. Luckily, there are things that we can know without needing proof, without needing to even leave the house, things that we can know as true by reason alone. These are things that we know a priori. An example would be the statement "all bachelors are unmarried." I don't have to go survey every bachelor on earth to know that that is true. All bachelors are unmarried because that's how we define the word bachelor. Of course, you have to know what the words bachelor and unmarried mean in the first place. Oh, you do? Okay. Perfect. That's great. But how do you know?

This time I mean functionally, how do you know? Where is knowledge biologically in the brain? What are memories made out of? We are a long way from being able to answer that question completely but research has shown that memories don't exist in the brain in single locations. Instead, what we call a memory is likely made up of many different complex relationships all over the brain between lots of brain cells, neurons. A major cellular mechanism thought to underlie the formation of memories is long-term potentiation or LTP. When one neuron stimulates another neuron repeatedly that signal can be enhanced overtime LTP, wiring them more strongly together and that connection can last a long time, even an entire lifetime. A collection of different brain cells, neurons that fire together in a particular order over and over again frequently and repeatedly can achieve long-term potentiation, becoming more sensitive to each other and more ready to fire in the exact same way later on in the future. They're a physical thing in your brain, firing together more easily because you strengthen that pattern of firing. You memorized. This branching forest of firing friends looks messy, but look closer. It could be the memory of your first kiss. A living souvenir of the event. If I were to go into your brain and cut out those cells, could I make you forget your first kiss or could I make you forget where your fingers are? Only if I cut out a lot of your brain. Because memories aren't just stored in one relationship, they're stored all over the brain. The events leading up to your first kiss are stored in one network, the way it felt to the way it smelled in different networks, all added up together making what you call the memory of your first kiss.

How many memories can you fit inside your head? What is the storage capacity of the human brain? The best we can do is a rough estimate, but given the number of neurons in the brain involved with memory and the number of different connections a single neuron can make Paul Reber at Northwestern University estimated that we can store the digital equivalent of about 2.5 petabytes of information. That's the equivalent of recording a TV channel continuously for 300 years. That's a lot of information. That is a lot of information about skills you can do and facts and people you've met, things in the real world. The world is real, right? How do you know?

It's a difficult question, but it's not rocket science. Instead, it is asking whether or not rocket scientists even exist in the first place. The theory that the Sun moved around the earth worked great. It predicted that the Sun would rise every morning and it did. It wasn't until later that we realized what we thought was true might not be. So, do we or will we ever know true reality or are we stuck in a world where the best we can do is be approximately true? Discovering more and more useful theories every day but never actually reaching true objective actual reality. Can science or reason ever prove convincingly that your friends and YouTube videos and your fingers actually exist beyond your mind? That you don't just live in the matrix?

No. Your mind is all that you have, even if you use instruments, like a telescope or particle accelerators. The final stop for all of that information is ultimately you. You are alone in your own brain, which technically makes it impossible to prove that anything else exists. It's called the egocentric predicament. Everything you know about the world out there depends on and is created inside your brain. This mattered so much to Charles Sanders Peirce that he drew a line between reality, the way the universe truly is, and what he called the phaneron, the world as filtered through our senses and bodies, the only information we can get. If you want to speak with certainty you live in, that is you react to and remember and experience your phaneron, not reality. The belief that only you exist and everything else, food, the universe, your friends are all figments of your mind is called solipsism. There is no way to convince a solipsist that the outside world is real. And there is no way to convince someone who doubts that the universe wasn't created just three seconds ago along with all of our memories. It's a frightening realization that we don't always know how to deal with. There's even The Matrix defense.

In 2002 Tonda Lynn Ansley shot and killed her landlady. She argued that she believed she was in the matrix, that her crimes weren't real. By using the matrix defense, she was found not guilty by reason of insanity, because the opposite view is just way healthier and common. It's called realism. Realism is the belief that the outside world exists independently of your own phaneron. Rocks and stars and Thora Birch would continue to exist even if you weren't around to experience them. But you cannot know realism is true. All you can do is believe.

Martin Gardner, a great source for math magic tricks, explained that he is not a solipsist because realism is just way more convenient and healthy and it works. As to whether it bothered him that he could never know realism was true, he wrote, "If you ask me to tell you anything about the nature of what lies beyond the phaneron, my answer is how should I know? I'm not dismayed by ultimate mysteries, I can no more grasp what is behind such questions as my cat can understand what is behind the clatter I make while I type this paragraph." Humble stuff. What strikes me is the cat.

Cats do not understand keyboards, but they know the keyboards are a fun place to be. It's a great way to get the attention of a human, they're warm and exciting, surrounded by noises and flashing lights plus cats love to get their scent on whatever they can, a mark of their existence. We aren't that much different, except instead of keyboards we have the mysteries of the universe. We will never be able to understand all of them.

I don't buy the premise that things which are composed of things can't be counted. Imagine a stone. It is a stone, no matter if it lies on a mountain or if it is used in a wall of a house. The stone keeps being the stone when it is part of the house. But the house is a house because of stuff being arranged as a house - being arranged as a thing. So multiple things can build a new thing. A thing is not the sum of the things it's made of but that sum plus their arrangement plus it's function plus it's designation.
It's a bit like a piece of squared paper. There aren't just as many squares as there are little quares on this paper but also the many squares that consist of 4 small squares and 8 small squares and so on.

4:00 if you count "possible arrangements of things" it would be 2^(10^183) 7:50 using similar logic with "possible combinations of 'thoughts'" you get 2^(1.1664*(10^230)) possible thoughts. This is the amount of thoughts that would be thought of in the whole universe under optimal conditions. Assuming probability exists, if the computer contributed to just one giant thought, there are 2^(1.1664*(10^230)+1)-1 possible "great thoughts", and 2^(2^(1.1664*(10^230)+1)-1) thoughts formed from combinations of thoughts inside the great thoughts. This is the optimistic value for the maximum amount of possible thoughts in our universe.

Time itself is infinite

If any n number things can combine to form a new thing, then there are n! things in total. But if a thing is something and another thing at once, you need to consider how many combination of combinations of things that thing could be; so there are n!! things in total. But if the thing changed based on where it was in space and time, you would need a way to map the total number of places in the universe to the total number of thing. Therefore there are n!!^p^d things in the universe where p is a length in d dimensions. But if a thing is interpreted differently based on the opinion of a collection of things then the total number of things is (n!!p^3)^(n!!p^3). Let's scrap that though and consider this, there is a universe that contains a single machine that continuously prints digits of pi for a finite period of time. If every digit it prints is a new thing, are there an infinite number of things (for an infinite number of pi digits) or only a finite number of things (counting all the digits it has already produced)?
Bremermann's limit only counts for a classical computational system.

I think that there are 21 different things.
The up and down quarks which make up protons and neutrons, which in turn get held together by gluons to make up all atoms which make all elements and things, and the electrons which orbit atoms, along with photons which make up light are the most common ones. It can be argued that our thoughts are merely chemical and electrical pulses in our brain, which are all made of these elementary particles.
After that, there are charm, strange, top, and bottom quarks, along with electrons, muons and tau particles, and their respective neutrinos.
Then there are the Z and W bosons, then the Higgs boson.

Every physical thing is just another name for an arrangement of one of these particles, and every conceivable thing is just an arrangement of physical chemicals and electricity.

However, a thing's location (physical and temporal) is unique, and a different location makes it a different thing.
This means that the 4 dimensions that give everything a location are all seperate things, after which there is nothing else.

That's it. Every physical and conceivable thing is just an arrangement of 17 particles in 4 dimensions.

I don't agree with the number of physical things he said. 10^80. Ok, that's the number of fundamental particles. However, that's not the number of "things". If you have two particles, you can name that group a thing, and 3 particles another thing. Two things can create a new, third thing, even though the number of parts is smaller than the number of things they form. So, the number of possible physical things is all the possible combinations, without repetition, of the 10^80 particles in the universe.

We can't count all things because:

1. The set of real numbers (|R), a subset of the set of all things, is already uncountable. Any set larger than that would also be uncountable.

2. Russell's Paradox - A set of all things doesn't exist in the first place, with respect to Georg Cantor's set theory.

3. Even Zermelo-Fraenkel's (and corrollarily, Zermelo's) set theory does not allow the existence of a universal set.

This also makes the assumption that our method of converting language into binary is the most efficient way to do so. It is quite likely that such a thought machine would have a far more efficient way of doing so, perhaps thinking in binary directly. That being the case, the estimation for the bit count of a sentence of 600 is probably far higher than required and the number of thinkable things would be considerably higher still.

First of all, if a "thing" can be either a single particle or an arrangement of particles, then the number of things in the Earth's observable universe at its future maximum is not 10^80 but 2^10^80, the cardinality of the powerset of the set of elementary particles. Furthermore, as time progresses, these arrangements will constantly change. For instance, I think a car is a thing, and I think it's a different thing than the arrangement its raw materials had before it was made, even if they both contain the same atoms. So every moment sees new things created. Moreover, I think temporal patterns are things. For instance, I think humans are things, even though their constituent atoms are constantly changing. So a function from time to sets of particles is also a thing. If we want to do the usual thing for these estimates and break up time into divisions of the Planck time and calculate from the big bang to 10^100 years later (which is pretty arbitrary, but it's what you did), then we have a domain of cardinality 10^150 and as I said earlier, a range of cardinality 2^10^80, giving a total number of possible functions of (2^10^180)^(10^150) = 2^10^330 ≈ 10^10^329.5.

Separately, your calculation of the number of "possible thoughts" is simply a strict upper bound on the number of times a thing could be thought, not an actual estimate. For thermodynamic and other reasons, the true number is obviously much smaller. But in either case, both numbers are far smaller than 2^10^330.

@Vsauce Michael, I think number you provide is too small. Sure, there are "10^183" physical things in our universe at most, but from those things we can form composites, which are in turn also "things" with different interesting properties.
quarks > protons > complex nuclei > molecules/crystals > animals/plants/minerals > planets > stars ...

How many things can we make from those? It is the power of the set of all the subsets of the original set, or 2^(10^183). Saying this number is gigantic is an understatement as it dwarfs even the googolplex. However, if we study various connections between these objects we get an even bigger number:

2^(2^(10^183)) - 2^10^183 ~ 10^10^10^182.48.

Hold on @Vsauce I have a better way of calculating this :). Thoughts are made of particles (electrons, photons, quarks e.c.t.). So what I think really best describes the number of things in the universe is the number of possible subsets of those 10^80 particles. So obviously you can have 10^80 things in the form of single particles, but then you also have (10^80)/2 pairs of things and all possible permutations of those pairs of those things which is pretty astronomical. Then you have all possible triplets and their permutations, quadruplets and so on right up to the largest possible 'thing' which is the universe itself (you also include 'nothing' as a thing too). It turns out there is a really simple way of calculating this (the number of subsets of a set), and it turns out to be 2^n where n is simply the number of members of that set (in this case 10^80). So in fact there are actually 2^(10^80) possible things in the observable universe. Your number is a huge underestimate, this number is so large that I cannot write it in the 10^m form because m itself is a number on the order of 10^79!

I believe Michael made a mistake. When calculating the amount of different ideas, he simply divided the maximum "thinking" rate by the size of the average idea, expressed in a sentence, which he equates to about 80 bits.

The problem is that he assumes each of these ideas are different. If a thought is expressed in 80 bits, there are only a maximum of 2^80 possible different thoughts, or about 10^24.

Would it not be fair to say that, according to the definition of thing in the video, that there is an infinite number of things, because lets just say you can conceive of a grain of sand X, which is a thing. Certainly it can be assured that the amount of information contained in this set is finite as well. Sure, there are infinitely many numbers that can be thought of individually, but I've just represented all of them simultaneously, right in this sentence. This video is intoxicated with numbers to the point of ridiculousness. Try logic instead of simplistic calculations. "Things" are conceptually infinite by definition. You could just limit yourself to all the physical matter in a single room and you'll still be able to produce and infinite number of conceptual "things" out of all the possible arrangements and emergent epiphenomena.
Take traffic patterns for an example. There are a countable number of cars in a traffic system, and so this video might say "x amount of things" where x is the number of cars. But the number of PHENOMENA involved in that traffic system is limitless. Different flow rates, collision patterns, stoppages and random permutations...

@Vsauce Thought experiment: At around the 6m mark, you brought up the idea of the heat death of the universe, and explained that current estimates believe it to occur in 1-100t years. Assuming humans can live as long as we have energy to use, could we not then progress to a point where we could control fusion/fission appropriately? My position is that, if we could harvest atoms (of any particular flavor), and we were fully capable of controlling fusion AND fission, then theoretically, we could fuse atoms to make heavier ones, or better yet, break heavier ones down to lighter ones. If we could harvest enough light atoms (namely hydrogen), we could (with a ridiculous amount of energy) create a star. If this is possible, while our star is dying, and begins its merciless slow-burning onslaught of our solar system, we could, in theory, begin creating or accreting a new star somewhere else. Realistically, it wouldn't have to be as big as our star; just large enough to sustain life. Obviously, we then have to move the Earth to the new location, but all things considered, if the previous position is plausible, then I believe this is also possible. My physics knowledge is cursory, so I'm sure there are some big loopholes I'm missing here that crumble my hypothesis, but it was an interesting thought experiment to ride out. Thoughts?

There's a big mistake in the counting of the phycial things. He simply counted the number of planck lenghts fiting in the observable universe, but that number in no way counts the total number of physical things. You've made the assumption that each planck lenghts would be in the same state, but it clearly isn't so because the universe is not homogenous. What you said in this video is impossible. Physics time!

A Planck length is 1.606 x 10^-26 nano meters, which is deemed the smallest possible distance in the universe. This isn't possible, however, because every time you move, you are moving at least 1 Planck length for each movement you do.
This is where the problem comes in. If you move directly from one space in a quantum foam to the next, if this is the shortest distance possible, you are not moving between this length.  ...You see where this is going yet? No? Okay, well imagine moving the distance of your house in an instant, with no pauses, and no time passing as you do it. Scale this down to the Planck level, and now you should understand.

The reason this is impossible, is because you would be achieving infinite velocity, therefore occupying every single space in the universe at once. For the sense in saying that this is physically possible, it would require infinite energy, which said by Henry, would be the end of the universe.

This all means that there is no "smallest distance." There are infinite things you can imagine.

This is a bit of an older video, but I'll add my comment anyway.

You said something about thinking that I'm not entirely sure I can agree with; maybe I'm missing something, and if so, I'd be grateful if someone corrected me. 

To paraphrase: "...and with the assumption that the average thought takes a sentence to describe..."

I think that's such a gross simplification that it renders that whole calculation (about how many things can be thought) entirely useless.

The thing about thoughts is that they're very often intuitive, and a single connection can contain layers and layers of reasoning, which can often take entire papers to fully explain. Is the average thought that far in-depth? It depends on what you consider the 'thought' in its entirety.

Do we take into account the sensory information used to create those thoughts? What about the layers of latent knowledge stored in our brains that we draw upon to interpret our senses? Or are thoughts strictly new conclusions drawn about things? What about memories? Emotions?

Of course, such a calculation is only hypothetical - it's for fun, and I'm not even sure why I'm putting so much thought into this. But it struck me as kind of oversimplified.

I wonder how many more of these grossly simplified ideas there are in these videos.

Let's make some corrections here.

The mass of the universe isn't 3.4*10^60 kg. Based on the assumption that the computational machine in question has been optimally built (it becomes unusable at the heat death of the universe), the mass has to be calculated based on the critical density. That is, the density limit where the heat death starts occouring. At the mass of 3.4*10^60 the universe would collapse in on itself long before 10^100 years. So, we have to use the mass 1.46*10^53 kg - about a millionth of the original mass! Extrapolation from the number of stars also comes pretty close, 1.7*10^53.

Thus, we get 1.99 × 10^103 bits per second. 6.26 × 10^219 bits altogether. So, there are 7.83 × 10^216 things in the universe.

But wait! 800 bits is wrong! Totally wrong! When we calculate 2^800, we get 6.67 × 10^240. This is how many things you CAN describe with 800 bits. Why can't it be 799 bits? 2^799 = 3.33 × 10^240. You would have much more space if you use 799 bits. Or, you could use even lower number, like 750. Even more space.

We have to find a point where these two equations meet. The point where we can utilize the bits' potential. The point where 2^x is as small as possible and 6.26 × 10^219 / y is as large as possible.

I'm graphing it and I seem to be getting the answer of 721 bits. Now the whole thing makes sense.

Correct answer: there are 8.68 × 10^216 things in the universe.

Your “infinitely many numbers we can imagine” analogy doesn’t hold. Or it might, depending on your definition of ‘imagine’. If by imagine, you mean a person can essentially grasp how long/large it is, then there are only a finite number of such numbers. I’m not going to argue semantics, but for the sake of the argument I’m going to use that definition. We can’t possibly imagine pi by that definition because it’s infinitely long, nonrepeating and our heads would literally collapse into black holes due to the amount of information. That argument can be made for all irrational numbers, and a similar one can be made for extremely large numbers such as Graham’s number.

It boils down to this: There are an infinite number of integers, 0, 1, -1, 2, -2, …, but only a finite number of integers that our semi-evolved brains can comprehend. But then you might say, ‘what about fractions?’. If we define a fraction as the quotient of integers a and b (i.e. a/b, b=/=0), the textbook definition of what a rational number is, and the possibilities for both a and b are finite, then there are only a finite number of fractions we can imagine. A similar argument can be made for complex numbers of the form a + bi. That’s overcounting by a lot too. So we have…
(a finite number of rational numbers) + (0 irrational numbers) + (a finite number of complex numbers) = a finite number of numbers that we can imagine

The obvious first counterargument would concern the definition of the word imagine. We can imagine sqrt(2) as just that, but we can’t imagine it as the infinitely long, nonrepeating number that it really is. Another counterargument would be to say that a/b might be able to be expressed as c/d + f/g or cd/fg, but those are expressions and not a numbers. Complex numbers are not expressions; technically a/b is an expression but what I’ll say is that it’s "the most simplified version of an infinite possibility of other expressions”.

A thought on the number of ideas that could exist.  At the end of this video the total was calculated to be 1.458x10^227, but that was only the NUMBER of things that could be processed by the most perfect computer given all the time in the world.  Supposing those 1.458x10^227 things that the computer thought of were the whole numbers 1 through 1.458x10^227... We see that the computer missed many things, such as the number 1.458x10^227+1, and the number 1.458x10^227+2, not to mention egg salad sandwiches (which are also not included in the set of numbers from 1 to  1.458x10^227).  So it is clear that there are a finite number of things that can be thought, but an infinite pool from which we can pick things to think of.

Here's another mindbender:
What is the number of all physically distinct and all functionally unique variations of this moment's observable universe?
.
.
.
Let n be the number of discrete physical entities in the OU(i.e. all fundamental particles).
Let k be the number of planck volumes in the OU.
The answer is all permutations of n(n!) multiplied by all combinations of n over k(k choose n).
x = k!/(k-n)!
Working out that number and accounting for the assumptions made shall be left as an exercise to the astute reader.
In any case Wolfram Alpha chokes on the query.

The video's rationale is based on assumptions that are incorrect and even contradictory. The reflexion is interesting but the output has no validity.

The principle used to say that thoughts only exist when we think them applies to physical objects as well. A wave doesn't exist until we separate it from the ocean with our minds. There are no things isolated a priori in the universe. A human being, for instance, is actually made of many different cells, including numerous bacteria. It only exists as a separate entity when we think it into existence.

Particles and things aren't the same thing. A wheel is part of a car, but still they ammount to two things. A subatomic particle is part of a pencil, but still they ammount to two different things. "A thing is a 'think'", as said Alan Watts. There are as many things as we choose to so define.

I have to say that this is a well-done video. You might think that the question of how many things - either real or possible - could exist is trivially infinite, but there are profound physical reasons why the answer is actually finite. These have to do with the finite size and lifespan of the universe, and the limits on the information density of spacetime itself, and @Vsauce gives a great and accessible explanation.

The answer, if you're interested, is on the order of 10^183 possible physical items, and 10^227 possible thoughts. But you should watch the video to understand why.

(And for those of you who are into theology and have ever thought about the line in Kaddish that goes
"יהא שמיה רבה מברך... לעלה מכל ברכתא ושירתא... דאמירן בעלמא"
("May the holy name be blessed above all blessings and songs which are uttered in the world") and wondered just how much is that, well, now you know. 10^227.)

@Vsauce Imagine this thought experiment. Take a standard HD image, 1920x1080 pixels. Each pixel is usually made up of 3 bytes (red green and blue). Now imagine a computer going through all the possible pixel combination in this grid of pixels. This means that given enough time, we would have an HD image of everything that was, everything that will ever happen, and things that couldn't possibly happen (a picture of me with einstein?). Sure the number of possibilities is huge, but not infinite. We could have accurate pictures of the earth in all stages of it's lifetime for example. It would just be quite hard to pick out which ones are actually real and which ones are not.

The difference here lies in the concept of 'useable energy'.  As matter is condensed energy, in every chemical reaction a tiny amount of mass is lost.  This then becomes energy that has become non condensed and potentially unusable.  You can imagine this process compounds over time.  As this energy is dispersed matter becomes non compressed and ceases to be matter (as we know it), rather spread energy.  Therefore gravity ceases to exist in a meaningful way, and the energy becomes uniformly dispersed throughout the universe. Once this happens, this is referred to as the 'Heat Death' of the Universe.  It's a similar process to osmosis, on a much more complex level.  The water in osmosis becomes uniformly distributed among the parental body, in much the same way that energy will, after being released slightly in every chemical reaction.  It's in direct relation to the Second Law of Thermodynamics, which states that energy will be released and become dispersed from every process, much like a block of wood being chopped up.  Imagine you start with a plank.  Every action you make you chop that wood in half, and each piece left over is chopped in half by another action being made.  Eventually you reach a point where you have a large pile of woodchips which are completely unable to be chopped again.  They are equally dispersed, but useless.

Love your videos, Michael, but you lost me around 2:30 when you said there's no reason to double count and then you dismissed words. Words are things. They are building blocks. Words are very important. Words are not the things. I get that. Words are entirely different things from the things they represent. Saying you won't count them for purposes of this video makes the video null and void. 

I know you use Ben Franklin's sheep to explain this away, but when you name something, it becomes that too, even if in a metaphorical sense. Even if the tail is not a leg, if you call it a leg, that particular tail is now also a leg, cuz somebody, somewhere, attributed that word to it. Whether it's Ben Franklin or someone less important. For the very reason you dismiss counting words, that's all the more reason why you have to include words. The name of the thing is not the same as the thing itself. However, a name of a thing is itself also a thing, separate from the thing itself, and must be counted separately. 

Every time you count a thing, you MUST count that thing's name as well, cuz names are things, and oftentimes things have more than one word or name associated with them. A dog is both a dog, and a Bruno (or whatever its name is).. and it's also a pooch, and a doberman (or whatever breed it is), and probably a mutt too. There's pet names for things beyond pets, and there's even derogatory names for things. I won't cite examples cuz some people don't like cussing, but you know what I mean. Sometimes a dog may have different names over its lifetime if it has multiple owners. This goes on and on, and I know this is why you dismissed this exercise, cuz it'd warrant its own video, but words are things. Names are things. They're too important. You can't pretend they're not there and have this count mean anything. 

Every tangible thing outside our minds + 
Every intangible thing inside our minds + 
Every word aka name for each tangible and intangible thing. = OMGWTF

You could argue that once a combination of letters that make up a word is counted once, you don't have to count it again but you'd be wrong. The safe in the bank (vault) is not the same safe as the one on the baseball diamond (rule determinant). The letters look the same, but they're different words, so for each word, you have to count every permutation of definition for that word. Every time a word comes up that name is a new thing being counted, that word has to be counted, even if its been associated with billions of other things, cuz the word that refers to MY cellphone is not the same word as the one that refers to YOUR cellphone. Each cellphone is A cellphone but none of them are THE only cellphone. Each cellphone is a different cellphone so the word that represents my cellphone has a different definition than the word that represents your cellphone. 

Then there's every word that has been printed in every book in the world. Each and every word on a printed page is itself a thing and all these things make up the thing that is that page of that book, which is also a thing. And every copy of that book that has ever been printed also has words on every page and each of those words is a thing. And each letter of each word is also in and of itself a thing. And all the punctuation marks. You can't just count twenty-six letters and be done. The two T's in "letter" are different T's. You can't just count a period once, cuz the period at the end of this sentence is a different period from the period in the last sentence. Come to think of it, every youtube comment for every youtube video has words and letters and each of them are separate things too, and they would each need to be counted separately. 

Then there's multiple languages. Each language has its own word for each thing. So you'd have to count what Italians call a dog, and what Spaniards or Mexicans or Latinos call a dog. Same with cellphone. Same with every thing you've covered in English, you'd have to go through the entire process again in every other language mankind has ever conceived. Yes. Even esperanto. Sometimes it's the same word, but since it's an entirely different language, you have to count it again, cuz no in English is not the same as the no in Spanish. They are used in different ways, show up in sentence structure differently, etc. 

As Laurie Anderson once said, language is a virus. It's constantly growing and changing and adapting. Words are being made all the time. So while it might only take a few generations to count all the things, mankind will never stop counting all the words of things, which again, are also things; very important things, that shouldn't be so easily dismissed. Just sayin'.

You can't think half a planck length, or just count one more than infinity, or rather one more than a large number. Thoughts are abstractions, synthesized images of other objects. You see two different objects, and you can combine them in your mind into something different. That doesn't mean that such a thing really exists in your mind, you are not accounting for every atom, energy, cell, hair, internal organs and so on.. you are just putting the outside image of two things and mixing them.

Now take into account whats just been written here, and apply it to numbers, sure you can think of one more than 3, it's four right, you can see 4 in you mind, you have a grasp of 4 points. but when you talk about large numbers, you have zero understanding of it, you can't visualize billions of objects/points, most people can't even visualize 10 points in their mind. So to say counting 1 more than a high number makes it a number is wrong. the same goes for small scales. "half a planck length"

This topic is too abstract to be represented with numbers. You can't really define a "thing" correctly. For example, is a poodle a different thing from a corgi? They are both dogs after all. Even a better question is- is a poodle and a dog different things? And are 2 different poodles the same thing?

Bottom line, "thing" is too abstract. you can't count "things" if you don't have a good definition for it. Frankly, I don't think one exists. Trying to use math to define such vague, abstract topics is ludicrous.

"It's a thing if you can think about it, or talk about it. If you can call it a thing, it's a thing"

According to that definition, there is an infinite number things that you can think about. I do agree, at the moment, that there is a finite amount of physical things, but I don't understand why you don't include specific arrangements of physical things as things.

Thinkable Things:
Ok, so I am thinking of a number. The number is 327. This number is different than other numbers, and so it is a different thing than other numbers. I can even give it a specific name, three-two-seven.  Now pick any number, and lets call that number "n". That number is a thing, because you can think about it. 

The Interesting thing about numbers is that they can go to infinity. Humanity will never be able to think about each number, but we can pick any number and think about that specific one. Since we can think about any specific one of the infinite amount of numbers, there are an infinite amount of thinkable things. The number of possible thoughts is infinite, although not every possible thought will actually be thought, and so not every thing will be thought about.


Physical Things:
Michael talked about the number of elementary particles, but there are also things that are combinations of these particles. The simplest example that I can think of is this. Lets suppose that we live in a universe that have the following elementary particles: Peanut butter, jelly and bread. Individually these are all things. The sum of elementary particles in this universe is three. They are three things. 

In some places in this universe the arrangement of  these elementary particles is such that it creates a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Together, the elementary particles form a different thing. Now we can count four physical thing in this universe. The amount of physical things in the universe is therefore greater than the sum of its parts, although it would still be finite.

So if "things that can be imagined" are included, well, Georg Cantor (a famous mathematician) discovered (and proved) that even though infinity is "big", there are other "infinities" that are even BIGGER! That's right. He discovered that some infinities are bigger than others. For example, we know that there are an infinity of counting numbers like 1, 2 ,3 ..., and so on. But Cantor discovered that there are more (MUCH more) "irrational" numbers than counting numbers. In fact he discovered that there is an infinity of infinities, each bigger than the previous one. If you want to look this up, search for "transfinite" mathematics, or simple "Georg Cantor. BTW, his contemporaries thought he was crazy and he actually did have some mental problems, but his mathematics of the transfinite is solid and beyond dispute.

The amount of thoughts is, in fact, finite. Why? Because a thought it nothing more than a re-arrangement of physical objects inside of the mind of a sentient being. Assuming the largest mind possible (ie, a brain the size of the universe) there is a finite number of configurations of this mind, therefore this is a finite number of thoughts. By the way, if you think about it, yes, this accounts for all current thoughts, past thoughts, and future thoughts.

The number of possible thoughts, is ridiculously large, yes, but still finite. Even numbers. There is only so many numbers that can be possibly conceived.

Consider the number 100. To understand the theory of 100, your mind needs to use the limited molecules that make it up to configure it in a way so as to imagine 100. Well, the same applies for every number. So a human mind can only conceive so many numbers. Now given a mind the size of the universe, with 10^183 particles, the number of possible configurations would be 10^183 x 10^183 -1 x 10^183 -2 x 10^183 -3 etc. etc. and no matter how ridiculously large that answer is, that number is less than infinity, therefore it is finite.

Here's a fun idea I stumbled on: A standard 1080p monitor has 1920x1080 pixels each with 3 subpixels capable of 256 shades of grey. That means that there is a finite number of images that can be displayed on a 1080p monitor(it is a comically large number, all online calculators compute it as infinity). The fun bit is that that must necessarily include an image of every point in the universe from all possible angles, at all possible times. The image set would also necessarily include all possible futures.

@Shokakahn simply put hydrogen is the smallest atom an has only one electron in its valence orbit, while helium possesses two. These orbits are the lowest in energy (1s) and hold a max of 2 electrons when that orbit is filled. Very little energy is required for this to influence this electron as it is more unstable without its pair. That being said the pair is a more stable formation. Which is (in very simple terms) why we see such a great disparity between the reactivity of hydrogen and helium despite there proximity on the periodic table.

Michael stated that things that objectively exists in this universe is limited to 10^183 because the supposed minimum of any size is the planck length. In addition to not mentioning the fact that planck length is merely a theoretical construct, he assumes that the occupation of space is the definition of an object and the arbiter of its existence. But what about "things" that don't occupy space such as photons? How are we to know how many of these mass-less particles exist out there? We still have not discovered dark matter and dark energy which accounts to 95.4% of the universe. Atoms only make up 4.6 of the universe!

Furthermore, can we really separate any object from any other object(and therefore quantify) simply because they are the smallest possible unit of matter? Elementary particles are elementary particles because of other elementary particles. Particles relate to other particles in accordance to the rules and patterns of this universe. Can a single particle even exist without the other particles? To think of a single elementary particle is to think of the conditions, rules and physical laws that allow for that one particle to exist. In a sense,  it is impossible to think of "1" thing in the context of the universe without unintentionally referencing a necessary environmental constant...because the universe is really just "1" inter-connected thing. The only thing you can accurately and absolutely "count" is the universe as a whole.

What is brilliantly illuminated in this video is how people underestimate not only infinity, but also how people also under-imagine or underestimate large numbers such as 10^180. 10^180 is such a huge number that, for humans, it is virtually infinite. But it isn't. I've never acknowledged the idea that the human population was actually that small that we wouldn't even fit the grand canyon, nor the idea that the total number of sand grains is just a mere 7.5 x 10^18. Let alone that everything ever exist has or will could be reduced to a mere 10^180. Infinity is truly beautiful. Maybe the only way for it to be properly and empirically represented is not through the universe but through multiverses.

Total number of thoughts possible? I don't think that's the same as the total number of thoughts that actually happen. And, if two people think about the same thing, it's still only one thing. This is an interesting question because we could talk about the total number of atoms in the universe, the total number of quarks and electrons that make up those atoms. But, everything identifiable made up of some of those atoms also counts as a separate thing. And I'm guessing that's a lot more than the total number of thoughts that humans have actually had in the total history of humanity. The latter is probably negligable. But, if you say how many things are there, not 'have been', then only currently existing thoughts (even if about the past) count anyway. Micheal, Here's my opinion: since a thing can be a concept or idea; something that can be imagined, then wouldn't it be safe to assume then that your definition of a thing would include something that can be written on a piece of paper? Like a theory or piece of information like a bit?  If that is the case, then I propose that the maximum number of things possible in the universe is in fact infinite.  The reason being that you could write the word grab on a piece of paper, and then bam! It's a thing. You could also write the number 2 and then Bam! it's also a thing. You could also do the same with the number 3, and four..... Do you see what I'm getting at?  The maximum number of things has to be infinite because the moment you come up with a maximum limit, you could always say: "Then what about that number plus one?"

Vsauce! You didn't make a good case for the physical objects. Why? Because a collection of things can itself be a thing. I am a thing. But I am made of cells, which are things. Those cells are made of atoms, which are things, etc.. To calculate an accurate number of things that can exist within our universe we need first the number of Planck volumes in our universe (10^183) plus the number of possible pairs of these objects (5 x 10^365) plus the number of possible triplets of things (1.67 x 10^548) and so on, until we get to the single possible thing made of all 10^183 Planck volumes (the universe itself). Since there is such a magnitude difference between the terms, this entire series will be dominated by the largest term, where each term is given by "n choose k" = n!/(k!(n-k)!). The largest term occurs at k = 5 x 10^182, and by using Stirling's approximation we obtain an estimated number of possible things in the observable universe as 10^(3 x 10^182). 
So, if you were to write this number with one digit per Planck volume, it would take one third of the universe just to write the number itself.

The animal with the largest brain is the sperm whale. Let's assume that a sperm whale can have any thought a human can. The number of neurons in the sperm whale hasn't been measured, so let's estimate. The human brain has approximately 85 billion (subtitle: 85,000,000,000 ;) ) neurons and weighs ~1,400g. The sperm whale's brain weighs ~7,800g, so it has approximately 473,500,000,000 neurons. If a neuron can have two states, and a thought is the combined state of every neuron in the brain, then the total possible number of thoughts is ~2^473,500,000,000. Which is 10^142,537,702,947. Or 1,000^47,512,567,649. It would take 47,512,567,649 commas to write out this number. If humanity ends within the next few thousand years, we could assign every human who ever lived a digit in this number, and still have plenty of digits to spare.

Actually, the real number would be even larger, because I rounded down at some points in my calculations. But you get the idea.

There are some complicating factors that didn't enter the discussion yet, most prominently the so called "emergent properties". By definition, these are phenomena unpredictable from the sole existence of the elements involved, and can only rise to existence once those elements interact. It's put down to layman's terms as "the total is bigger than the sum of its parts", and technically speaking is due to the many non-linearities present in the real world. For instance, an orbital in an atom can only come from the interaction of the electron and the nucleus. This might seem unnecessary at first, but this concept is extensively used in biology to try and explain the "appearance" of life and consciousness. Just think about colors: does the white in the Youtube background exist? If so, how many colors could there be? Of course, a safe answer would be: as many as can be detected by living brains. But then, the colors are not made of elementary physical particles, right? This would extend the number of existing things with emergent properties like "color". And since it depends on the interactions of "elementary things" (elements of a system), the actual number of such objects could get much greater than 10 to the 180th power (since the combinations increase factorially with the number of elements involved, although in non-linear ways). To complicate matters even further, there's no way to determine "true" emergent phenomena other than common sense as of yet (unless we agree with some restricting definition).

Other point is that we cannot imagine every possible number. We need a way to represent numbers in order to think of them, the most basic manner being in binary form, that takes a bit of information for each digit. Well, since there's a minimal amount of energy involved in the transference of one bit, one cannot think of increasingly longer strings of binary digits as it would require increasingly greater amounts of energy in our brains. There's a limit to the amount of energy present in a given volume at which a singularity will form and thus no more information could be stored at that volume (though the singularity would likely expand).

But what if you take into mind combinations of those elementary (real) "things"? For example: a teddybear consists of a LOT of atoms and is a thing too!
I did a quick calculation:

The total number of combinations of R thing possible with a finite number N things can be calculated by:

n!/(r! (n - r)!)

If you want ALL combinations possible (a summation of all R's from 1 to N) you get this approximate formula for this:

Total combinations possible = 10^(0.3010300 n).

Fill in n = 10^183 and you get a total number of possible physical "things" in the order of 10^10^183, that's a LOT more than a GOOGLEPLEX!!


Just thought you guys might want to hear this :)

Your idea was to count material things and then thoughts, but the way you did this might be inconsistent, I think. When you counted material things you only counted smallest particles or smallest possible measurable things. You didn't count objects (like individual apples, dogs, houses, etc.), which is very understandable because those are all different configurations of the smalles particles. So I definitely agree with that.

But then you started counting thoughts, and that is where it got inconsistent. Thoughts are neurons that interact with each other in a certain way, and neurons are made of particles. So thoughts are, in a way, made of particles too, they're material things.
So either you just assumed dualism (which is totally defendable, by the way), or you counted some constellations of particles as things and others not.

One problem I have with this, and one solution.

- I'm tired of hearing this idea of "many universes". It's a misleading misnomer. I'm not object to branching realities or parallel realities, but the "uni" in "universe" means "one"; "singular". Any parallel realities are just part of the universe. If we discover a separate plane of existence, it just means that the universe was bigger than we thought.

- As for how many things are there in the universe, and this may be subject to criticism (as I hope it will), but since we are all made up of the same exact energy as everything else, the universe only contains one "thing": itself. It's our perspectives that lead us to discriminate between "things", which is fine for practical reasons, but if we're tracking infinitesimal ideas, then the only thing in the universe is the universe itself.

Unfortunately there is a big flaw with this argument. Check 2:10 "Let's assume that numbers and math and the laws of physics exist". If numbers exist, then you have to add them to the total, and that puts the number to infinity.

Interesting train of thought, but this is not how I would go about it.

The total number of the "smallest possible things" is counted, where the latter is defined as a cube with a side equal to a Planck length.

However you can easily fit two things in the same space (think for example of ripples in a vat of water; you can introduce more sources of ripples and they will happily coexist). More-over we may count the number of "smallest things" in this way, but objects consist of several arrangements of these smallest things - so you have to count all permutations.

So here is an alternative calculation.

I would define the smallest things as those objects with Compton wavelength equal to twice the radius of the observable universe. Using the maximum estimate of 62 billion light years, that corresponds to an object with a rest mass of ca 1.87*10^-69 kg (several orders of magnitude lighter than the estimated mass of neutrinos).

Now, thinking of an object of critical mass and a Schwarzschild radius of 62 billion light years we get a mass estimate of ca 4*10^53 kg. Therefore, you can fit up to 2.1*10^122 "smallest objects" in the observable universe.

The total number of permutations is (2.1*10^22)! = approx. 10^10^10^2.09485 which is more than a googolplex (10^10^10^2).

And if you think that there is a correspondence between a thought an some "things" in the universe, they will be included in that estimate.

Of course, this analysis assumes that two of the "smallest possible things" are distinguishable in such a way that it makes sense to speak of permutations, but this is assumed in the video as well and it is clear that two items with the same energy at rest may well be different "things", justifying the need to speak of permutations.

This is kind of a nice mathematical puzzle, but I really can't see the philosophical or epistemological point to it. All this does is set the mathematical upper bound for the number of 800bit sequences a computer made of all the matter in the universe could make. 

In this case however, I would hesitate to define these sequences as "thoughts" or "ideas." They might be more accurately characterized as "expressions" or something of that nature. In order for a thought or idea to have epistemological weight it must refer to something other than itself. For the idea of a pig with wings to become a manifest "thing" in my mind, it must refer to my experience and conception of pigs, wings etc. I find it difficult to imagine a scenario in which the "things" produced by this supercomputer would be anything but meaningless bits of energy and self reference.

Your number is so much bigger than that. Let 10^183=N (what you calculated). That's only the number of things that fit into the observable universe. But those things can be combined to form other things. Those things can, in time, divide or unite to form yet other things. We have the formula for arrangements An^k (k is written above n) = n!/(n-k)!. Now, the total of unique ways of arranging the N things is  Sum(An^k) for k=1 to n. That gives us a total of just under N! x e, where e is Euler's number (approx 2.72). That is approx. 2.72x(10^183)!, where you add 1.458x10^227. This number is calculated at ONE TIME, since, as I've said, the things can combine or divide. It is even greater than that, since those arrangements are on 3 dimensions, whereas this formula works if you place the things in a row... (sorry for any calculation errors).

Maybe a good estimate to get "Everything" is to get "Every possible distribution of matter in our observable universe" which would include things that are imagined, things that physically exist, things that COULD physically exist and things that COULD be imagined. This would include every possible inclination of our universe and any universe that could exist under the same physical conditions. So this is not just everything that IS, but everything that COULD BE (assuming physical constants are the same)

  To do this, we can assume that there 10^80 atoms in our universe and we'll assume that atoms are the base-bit that can be re-arrange (we won't use subatomic particles because then it'd get too complicated, but would make the answer even bigger). We'll assume that the smallest measurement of distance is the planck length (1.616*10^-34), in which case we can come up with a planck volume (4.22*10^-105). The observable universe is about 3.5*10^80 m large, we can then say that the 10^80 atoms have 8.293*10^184 different positions they could be in (we'll assume positions next to each other lead to composite atoms, remember this is just a rough estimate)

  Using arrangements, we can come up with the total number of combinations that occur with this measurement. Because physics tells us that every elementary particle is the same as any other elementary particle of the same type, we'll say that atoms are not unique, but the positions they can occupy are (Again atoms aren't elementary particles, but it's a useful approximation). This is a GIANT number, so big that no calculator, even on the internet, can appropriately express it. Unfortunately this means to express it, it must be algebraic. If we let n = 10^80 and k = 8.293*10^184, then the answer is

(n+k-1)! / (k-1)!n!

This number is absolutely massive, probably more than 10,000 zeros.

Amazing video, but I have a few questions:
- Assuming you used ASCII to describe a thought, wouldn't it be possible to create a new computer language that is a lot more efficient and therefore takes less memory?
- For the string you counted every individual as unique, but did you do that for the thoughts as well? This brings up a split road: if so, any thought can be as short as possible (the thing with the smallest description). However if not so, an amount of unique things of your quantity would get enormously long description that takes a lot more processing time.
- The "description" of a thing I find an undefined idea. Assuming things need to be unique, in order not to get replicates of things, you need to be as precise as possible, resulting in chapters of books per thing, varying with the complexity of a thing.
- Things can be combined to make other things. I can use strings to create up and down quarks and gluons to make protons and neutrons, and combined with electrons and bosons I can create atoms which create molecules which create matter as we are common with it. You would need a whole sum of possible particle combinations while keeping in mind the laws of nature.
- All the matter in the universe is an easy, but improper way to measure the size of your "thinking machine". Firstly because energy can be converted into matter, making up for a portion of the machine (but I don't know if it's significant). Secondly, the biggest part of the universe is made of hydrogen, which needs to be turned into the necessary stuff needed for the machine, like crystals and silicon (and again, you could assume we could change ALL of the hydrogon, without any energy loss, into the machine compartments, though I'm not sure if that's simply possible).
- And as a funny side note, if you use all the matter in the universe to create a thinking machine, you don't have any mass to create other things with. Unless you say that we want the amount of hypothetical things, but then again we might as well turn our thinking computer on for an infinite universe lifetimes.
- Can existing and thought things be the same? If I see a rock or if I think of said rock, are those the same things? Why not, or why so?
- Furthermore there are similar or nitpicky problems, like the fact that the machine would likely collapse due to its own gravity, destroying the machine.
If any of my points are redundant or simply faulty, I'd like to hear of you.

I feel there's a lot of things missing. It's like you're counting all the individual lego pieces but not all the possible lego constructions you could make with them. I think  you forgot counting not only all the possible subsets of planck volumes, but also all the possible ways to arrange the tiny volumes in each subset given the whole universe's size.

The biggest problem with this concept: duplicate "thoughts".
You can only have so many sentences you can form with a language and more words would at some point require more letters or longer sentences, which would push the bits required. A lot more letters would also increase the amount of bit-combinations required for a letter.
Assuming we now use a machine, it'd need to go over already existing thoughts to see if it created a duplicate and so on and so forth.

When you upscale aspects of computing like this, it'll have a lot of extreme foreseen and unforeseen diminishing returns.

this video is incredible. one thing though. you talked about breaking down objects into elementary particles and treating thoughts as though they were separate. I understand the logic behind counting the number of individual thoughts you can have except for one thing. Your thoughts can be simplified into elementary particles. They are not non-physical, thoughts exist inside your brain as an arrangement of chemicals and synapses, just as mater exists as an arrangement of particles. Except that synapses and chemicals can be further broken down into elementary particles. If you imagine an elephant, you don't make that elephant come into being. What is happening is your brain uses a finite number of chemicals and synapses to push that elephant into your consciousness. The elephant doesn't actually exist, what actually exists as an arrangement of synapses and chemicals which in turn exist as elementary particles. That is why I believe individual thoughts shouldn't be counted. Just a thought though...

I wonder what would actually happen near the heat death of the universe.
Like, that would basically mean, all particles that exist in the entire universe, including the unobservable parts, have dispersed into vacuum, right?
But at that point, would that not be a state similar to what we imagine the time before the universe to be?
If there was zero heat (0K) and thus 0 Energy everywhere, that would mean we would know a precise Energy. But that, in turn, would give infinite uncertainty to time. Time would cease to exist.
And quantum fluctuations in general would randomly cause arbitrarily sized particle pairs to spawn and annihilate.
And there probably are some other things related to uncertainty and 0-point energy and such that I'm not considering right now.
But basically, those conditions should be very similar to those of the origin of the universe. And thus, eventually, after a physically arbitrary, physically unknowable amount of time, a new universe would be born. - Literally any time period from instantly to infinitely long would be equally good as assumption for time wouldn't even make sense.

And even as we approach the heat-death, time uncertainties must grow quickly. All clocks (Every structure suitable for time measurement that even still exists at the time, which, by definition, are not very many) would become increasingly inaccurate.

So the amount of 'things' in the physical world is equal to the amount of Planck volumes that can fit in the observable universe. What about 'things' that make up other 'things'?

E.g. A horse is a thing, but a horse also has a tail, which is a thing - 2 different things sharing the same physical matter. Same with an atom - its a thing, but so is its components (electrons, protons).

This would mean that the amount of 'physical' things would be exponentially larger than 10^183. In fact, I very much doubt it is even measurable - the computer measuring would run out of memory long before this number could be calculated.

One thing that blows my mind is IPv6 addresses...

The amount of addresses available with IPv6 is really incredibly mind-boggling.

It's enough addresses for many trillions of addresses to be assigned to every human being on the planet. 

The earth is about 4.5 billion years old. If we had been assigning IPv6 addresses at a rate of 1 billion per second since the earth was formed, we would have by now used up less than one trillionth of the address space. 

The earth's surface area is about 510 trillion square meters. If a typical computer has a footprint of about a tenth of a square meter, we would have to stack computers 10 billion high blanketing the entire surface of the earth to use up that same trillionth of the address space.

It can support 2^128 Internet addresses -- 
340,282,366,920,938,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 of them to be exact. 
2^32 = 4.4 x 10^9 addresses (IPv4)
2^128 = 3.4 x 10^38 addresses (IPV6)
That is 6.7x10^19 addresses. 15 billion IPV4 internets per sq.cm of Earth’s surface! 

Assuming the most number of grains of sand - around 10^24 - 294 femtopercent (yes, femto, 10^-15) would be used if every grain were allocated an IP. You could allocate 340 billion planets with the same number of grains of sand before you even came close to filling up the address space. After all that, you'd still have 2.8x10^35 addresses free.

What a contentious metaphysics. Macro objects aren't just names for molecular clusters, composite objects are things which are over and above the parts from which they are composed. For example, when someone cuts his hair, he is loosing many molecules, and yet he stays the same person and thus the same object because his name doesn't change reference. This means that the particular set of molecules which composes a person at a time, is accidental to his identity (and the same is true of trees and rocks and stars etc.). So on this view, a space occupied by an object made of 100 atoms contains at least 101 objects: each of the atoms + the composite object.

let me explain you a thing

I had an interesting discussion with one of my mathematician colleagues the other day about this sort of thing. He claimed that the amount of possible thoughts was indeed (countably) infinite, and argued it by induction. He said that if you can think about the number n you can think about the number n+1, therefore the amount of numbers you can think about is unbounded.

Now this argument conflicts heavily with the physical reality that there are a finite number of particles (even going down to the fundamental level) in your neurological system that generates thoughts and mental states. Therefore even if you wanted to arrange them in every possible way, any way you think of doing it will give you a finite number of states at the end of the day. We also know that mental states are actually fairly broad as far as the states in which they can arise, and as such there is a huge amount of states which give rise to the exact same "thought." This implies that the set of numbers you can think about is indeed finite, but you could also imagine that a conscious organism's neural existence could grow slowly over time, giving it the ability to think of more and more numbers. This would also rely on the universe being unbounded as well, however. 

This got me thinking about what it even means to "think" about something. It seems intuitive that if I can think about a number n then I can think about n+1, but the argument itself only actually uses 2 "numbers" which are really just abstract concepts which are two thoughts. If I think about the "set of all natural numbers" or even the "set of all infinite decimal numbers" (which is uncountable) then I'm not really producing a countably or uncountably infinite number of thoughts, but actually just two thoughts about each of these entities. We like to think of the way we define mathematical objects as "being" those objects in a real way, but really the objects are merely the finite symbols we use in the definition. Kurt Gödel was the mathematician who really plowed through this field and elucidated a vast array of these ideas, so if anyone reading this finds the subject interesting I would suggest reading about his work.

I think the number of physical things is not simply the number of particles in the observable universe, or the number of things that could fit in the observable universe (planck length bit), but rather, arrangements thereof. despite the fact that a guitar and a washing machine could be made up of the exact same fundamental particles, they are clearly not the same "thing" - they have certain qualities that differentiate them. therefore, a "thing" is just a particular arrangement of fundamental particles. to find the total number of possible arrangements of every fundamental particle in the known universe, the factorial of (10^80) must be calculated. 
this is an absolutely ridiculous number. wolfram alpha says that (10^80)! is equal to 10^10^10^1.9133, or 10^24999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999986 (there are 249...986 trailing zeros) 
this is a completely unimaginable number (though not as big as graham's number - go watch that numberphile video). I assert that there are this many possible things, and that thought doesn't count when compared to the number of possible combinations of fundamental particles.
to be fair, most of them would be completely unrecognizable and could possibly be discounted as things, depending on how you regard my first statement.

I have a great idea for a Vsauce episode! "What Did Dinosaurs Really Look Like? Have you ever noticed that dinosaurs all look pretty much exactly like their skeletons with a bit of meat stretched over them? That isn't how animals work. In fact, there isn't a single animal in all of nature that looks like its skeleton covered in a thin layer of skin. All creatures big and small have fleshy bits that have nothing to do with their skeletons. Why would Dinosaurs be an exception? For example, chickens have frock dangling off the tops of their heads, and humans have ears and noses which would not be apparent from looking at our skeletons. When Dinosaurs walked the Earth, they probably didn't look like their skeletons at all. Its some grey area between countably and uncountably infinite, depending on your definitions of things. Otherwise:

If we exclude abstract notions, as we can't possibly ever actually think them even if we tried, the maximum number of distinct possible objects in the universe is a very large, yet calculably large, number. This number is  2^(10^61 * ((10^183)!)).

Apologies for the wall of text, and feel free to refute me if you find any errors in my math.

-Planck units are the smallest physically possible units given our current understanding of physics, as they are bound by constants such as the speed of light, so there can be, as you stated, 10^183 different Planck volumes in the observable universe. Nothing smaller is possible given our current understanding of the laws of physics, so lets use that as a point for our fundamental particle.

-We don't know if there are specific fundamental units, but if we assume there is a different/distinct Planck volume at each 10^183 individual possible position, that leaves us with (10^183)! possible permutations of them. This is the total number of states the observable universe could ever possibly be in.

-Now, since we can define any physical object as any possible distinct subset of this, it is the total number of distinct subsets of all 10^183! permutations, or 2^((10^183)!). Since electrons are on a much larger scale than the Planck volume, this will include every possible arrangement of thoughts and memories stored in brains, every possible file on any computer, so it will include every possible distinct thought at any distinct moment, any possible song or book or paper, etc.

Now if we want to say, well hey, thoughts themselves might be 4-dimensional, lets factor in time. I'm not going to go into more dimensions than this, as I'm sticking strictly in what we currently can observe, but lets consider time, as this will even give us motion vectors, so it'll give us every sound ever made and every signal ever sent out - effectively every piece of data to ever exist.

The universe can be in any of these (10^183)! states at any individual time, and the smallest measurable unit of time is a Planck second. There have been about 10^61 Planck seconds (iirc) since the universe has "started". Discounting expansion and all that stuff, that means that each of these 10^61 planck seconds could have had the universe in any of (10^183)! possible permutations, or a total of 10^61*((10^183)!) possible 4 dimensional permutations of the observable universe from the start of time till now.

Since any distinct possible subset of these permutations can be considered a unique object, there is an upper max of 2^(10^61 * ((10^183)!)) possible objects that could ever have existed up until this point. This includes every sound ever made, every electromagnetic signal (light, radio, gamma, etc) ever broadcast... Anything that has ever happened or could have ever happened is included.

So given your definition on what a "thing" is, there is a number. A very large number, but I just gave it to you.

that is, if the "thoughts" are only based off of things that already exist as computers don't have the capability of true human imagination. Computers can only think inside the box, literally: input and output. You would need to input things to get "thoughts" out of the computer and those thoughts would merely be combos of things we input. Things that already exist which doesn't include things that have yet to be discovered. People have the ability to think abstractly. Granted, most of our own thoughts are based off of things that already exist, but we are not as limited by that as computers are.

When you were talking about the possible combination of bits of data in an audio clip, It got me thinking. A 1080p monitor has 2073600 pixels, each one able to display 16581375 colors. That leaves 2073600^16581375 different combinations of pixels/colors to comprise an image. Every possible object in every possible scene from every possible angle in every possible color. If you think about it a computer left to randomly generate images would reproduce the mona lisa, or you as an infant playing with your toys back in 1973 on kodachrome quality film. It would produce the very picture on your screen right now as you read this comment. It would produce every language, even those that don't exist. It seems as if there are an infinite amount of choices, but a (albeit astronomical) finite number of outcomes. I mean heck, it could produce the text that could tell us how to cure every known disease.

Beatiful ending, I'm just having a problem with it... you make it sound like there are more thoughts than physical things, but that's not what you calculated. You just calculated the hypothetical upper limit for each of those, and compared those. That has no application to reality whatsoever

Also, you made so many assumptions, that the final result for the amount of thoughts is just completely arbitrary. You didn't take into account the gradual decrease of total energy (reducing the total thought count), and you didn't take into account that there's a gazillion times less thinking matter than 'dumb matter' in reality, so there's no way there are more thoughts.
In other words, the conclusion:
"when it comes to every thing in the universe, it really is the thought that counts."
can't possibly be drawn based on the rest of the video. When it comes to the maximum amount of every hypothetical thing in the universe, it is indeed the thought that counts. In reality, it's mostly dead stuff though.

PS: that doesn't mean thoughts don't count. Even though there are in reality way fewer thoughts than things, that doesn't mean those fewer thoughts aren't way more important than those huge amounts of things. Without thoughts, we wouldn't be here.

I don't think that reducing all the physical things to elementary particles works. For instance, if I take 500 trees and mill the wood. I have now a new thing, namely a quantity of boards, but the same matter. Even if you want to say that we should count the particles, we still have additional arrangements of the matter that formally is a new thing. The essence or quiddity of a thing is not it's matter but its form. Those planks could easily be made into a ship and then torn apart to make several thousand chairs. you would then have created and destroyed multiple different things, because each of the things has a different form. It isn't a matter (no pun intended) of matter, but of form which gives a thing its thingness.
